title: 107_s1359
content: The Act is titled the "Facilitating Access to Speedy Transmissions for Networks, E-commerce and Telecommunications (FASTNET) Act." Congress finds that the Telecommunications Act of 1996 aimed to promote competition and reduce regulation in telecommunications markets to deploy advanced technologies to all Americans. The Act recognized the unique circumstances of local exchange carriers with fewer than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines. The Telecommunications Act of 1966 acknowledged the unique position of local exchange carriers with less than two percent of the nation's subscriber lines, allowing them to accelerate the deployment of advanced services in less populated regions. Two percent carriers are uniquely positioned to accelerate the deployment of advanced services and competitive initiatives for consumers in less densely populated regions. Existing regulations often impose disproportionate burdens on these carriers, hindering their ability to provide advanced telecommunications services in less populated areas. Reducing regulatory burdens on two percent carriers will allow them to allocate more resources to deploying advanced services and competitive initiatives for consumers in less densely populated regions, overcoming obstacles imposed by existing regulations tailored for larger carriers. Reducing regulatory burdens on two percent carriers will enable them to allocate more resources to deploying advanced services and competitive initiatives for consumers in less densely populated regions of the Nation. This will increase their ability to respond to marketplace conditions and accelerate the deployment of services to benefit consumers. Reducing regulatory burdens on two percent carriers will accelerate the deployment of advanced services and competition in the telecommunications industry, benefiting consumers in less densely populated regions of the Nation. The Act aims to reduce regulatory burdens on local exchange carriers to promote competition and benefit consumers nationwide. The Act aims to accelerate the deployment of advanced services and competition in the telecommunications industry by reducing regulatory burdens on local exchange carriers with fewer than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines. This will benefit consumers in all regions of the Nation and allow carriers to redirect resources to increasing initiatives. The Act aims to reduce regulatory burdens on local exchange carriers with fewer than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines to improve flexibility and allow resources to be redirected to increasing investment in initiatives. SEC. 3. DEFINITION. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to define a "two percent carrier" as an incumbent local exchange carrier with fewer than a certain number of access lines. The Communications Act of 1934 defines a "two percent carrier" as an incumbent local exchange carrier with fewer than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines. SEC. 4. REGULATORY RELIEF FOR TWO PERCENT CARRIERS. An amendment to Title II of the Communications Act of 1934 introduces reduced regulatory requirements for "two percent carriers." The Commission must consider the impact of regulatory requirements on two percent carriers when adopting rules for incumbent local exchange carriers. If the Commission fails to do so, they cannot enforce the rule against two percent carriers until they evaluate the burden separately. The Commission must evaluate the impact of regulatory requirements on two percent carriers when adopting rules for incumbent local exchange carriers. If they fail to do so, the rule cannot be enforced against two percent carriers until a separate evaluation is conducted. The Commission is not required to conduct a separate evaluation if rules do not apply to two percent carriers or if they are exempt. Differentiation based on carrier size is allowed by law. This section applies to rules adopted after its enactment date. SEC. 282 limits reporting requirements for carriers, with differentiation based on carrier size allowed by law. This section applies to rules adopted after its enactment date. The Commission is limited in requiring certain reporting from carriers, with exceptions for small carriers. The Act preserves the Commission's authority, except for the specified limitations. The Act allows carriers to comply with Commission rules and file ARMIS reports, excluding section 224. The Commission's authority to access information is preserved for two percent carriers, with exceptions outlined in the Act. The Act allows carriers to comply with Commission rules and file ARMIS reports, excluding section 224. The Commission's authority to access information is preserved for two percent carriers, with exceptions outlined in the Act. SEC. 283 addresses the integrated operation of two percent carriers. The Commission does not require two percent carriers to have separate affiliates for various services, including local and interexchange services, mobile radio services, internet, and other enhanced services. Additionally, two percent carriers and their affiliates are not mandated to maintain separate personnel, facilities, departments, or operations. SEC. 284. Participation in tariff pools and price cap regulation. SEC. 284 outlines the rules for participation in tariff pools and price cap regulation. A two percent carrier can choose to participate or withdraw from a common line tariff for a study area without obligation for other areas. The carrier must give 60 days notice and the election is binding for one year. The Commission may require a two percent carrier to give 60 days notice of its intent to participate or withdraw from a common line tariff for a study area. The carrier's election is binding for one year. Additionally, a two percent carrier can choose to be regulated by the Commission under price cap rate regulation for one or more study areas. A two percent carrier may elect to be regulated by the Commission under price cap rate regulation for one or more study areas, with the election being binding for one year from the date of the election. "SEC. 285. DEPLOYMENT OF NEW TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES BY TWO PERCENT COMPANIES." The Commission allows two percent carriers to introduce new interstate telecommunications services with only one day's notice, without needing approval for the rate structure. The term 'new interstate telecommunications service' refers to services not previously offered by the carrier. The Commission allows two percent carriers to introduce new interstate telecommunications services with only one day's notice, without needing approval for the rate structure. The term 'new interstate telecommunications service' refers to services not previously offered by the carrier, expanding service options for ratepayers. "SEC. 286. ENTRY OF COMPETING CARRIER." "Two percent carriers can adjust their interstate rates with short notice and offer contract-based tariffs upon certification of competition in their service area." The telecommunications carrier must compute its interstate rate of return based on the nondiscounted rate for the service, upon certification of competition in its service area. The Commission will regulate a two percent carrier as non-dominant and not require tariffing of the interstate service if a local exchange carrier or its affiliate is engaged in facilities-based entry within the two percent carrier's service area. The Commission will regulate a two percent carrier as non-dominant and not require tariffing of the interstate service offerings if a local exchange carrier or its affiliate is engaged in facilities-based entry within the carrier's service area. The two percent carrier meeting certain requirements can participate in the common line tariff. A two percent carrier meeting specific requirements can participate in the common line tariff administered by the National Exchange Carrier Association. The term "facilities-based entry" is defined within the service area of a two percent carrier. The National Exchange Carrier Association administers a common line tariff that two percent carriers can participate in. "Facilities-based entry" in the service area of a two percent carrier involves providing local telephone exchange switching and service to at least one unaffiliated customer. The term 'carrier' refers to providing local telephone exchange switching and service to at least one unaffiliated customer. A 'contract-based tariff' is a tariff based on a service contract between a two percent carrier and its customers, including contract terms and service descriptions. A 'contract-based tariff' is a tariff based on a service contract between a carrier and its customers, including contract terms, service descriptions, volume commitments, and prices. The contract-based tariff includes a brief description of services, minimum volume commitments, contract prices, volume discounts, and other regulations affecting the contract rate. The curr_chunk provides details on volume discounts, classifications, practices, and regulations affecting the contract rate structure. The term 'service area' is defined in section 214(e)(5). "SEC. 287. SAVINGS PROVISIONS." The text chunk states that the Commission's authority under sections 201 through 208 is not restricted, rural telephone companies' rights are not diminished, and state authority over intrastate communications service is not limited by this part. The Commission's authority under sections 201 through 208 is not restricted, rural telephone companies' rights are not diminished, and state authority over intrastate communications service is not limited by this part. State authority shall not be affected by the guidelines and standards of the Commission as of the date of enactment. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON MERGER REVIEW. Amendment to the Communications Act of 1934 sets a deadline for making public interest determinations in mergers involving two percent carriers. The Commission must make required determinations and rule on any petitions related to the merger or acquisition. The Commission must make determinations and rule on petitions related to mergers involving two percent carriers within 60 days of receiving an application. If no action is taken within the specified period, the application will be approved. The Commission must approve or deny merger applications involving two percent carriers within 60 days. If no action is taken, the application is deemed approved without conditions. The Commission must approve or deny merger applications involving two percent carriers within 60 days. If no action is taken, the application is deemed approved without conditions. The Commission shall allow a two percent carrier to elect under section 284 for local exchange facilities acquired through a merger or acquisition subject to the review deadline. Effective Date: The provisions of this section apply to applications submitted to the Commission after the enactment of this Act. Pending applications will be subject to these requirements as if filed on the enactment date. SEC. 6. TIME LIMITS FOR ACTION ON PETITIONS FOR RECONSIDERATION OR WAIVER. Section 405 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a provision for expedited action by the Commission on petitions for reconsideration or waiver. The Commission must issue an order granting or denying such petitions within 90 days, or the relief sought will be deemed granted. The Commission must issue an order granting or denying petitions for reconsideration or waiver within 90 days. Failure to act within this period results in the relief sought being deemed granted. Enforcement of any rule subject to reconsideration will be stayed if the Commission fails to act within the 90-day period. If the Commission does not act on a petition for reconsideration within 90 days, enforcement of the rule in question will be stayed until the Commission issues an order. Any order issued or petition for waiver granted due to the Commission's inaction is considered final and can be appealed. The Commission must issue an order on a petition for reconsideration within 90 days, or enforcement of the rule will be stayed. Any order or waiver granted due to inaction is final and can be appealed. The provisions apply to petitions submitted after the enactment of the Act. The provisions of this section apply to any petition for reconsideration or waiver submitted to the Commission after the enactment of the Act. Pending petitions will be subject to these requirements as if they were filed on the enactment date. SEC. 7. NATIONAL SECURITY AND LAW ENFORCEMENT EXCEPTIONS. The 60-day and 90-day time periods under sections 310 and 405 of the Communications Act of 1934 do not apply if an Executive Branch agency with national security, law enforcement, or public safety jurisdiction submits a written filing to the Federal Communications Commission. If an Executive Branch agency with national security, law enforcement, or public safety jurisdiction advises the Federal Communications Commission that a petition or application may pose concerns beyond the 60-day or 90-day time limits, the Commission must address these issues.
